content: ELM GROVE, Wisc. (MarketWatch) — Bakken oil shale stocks have gotten a lot of attention online recently. Since I have written about Bakken stocks too, I recently decided to drive out to North Dakota to see first-hand what was really going on in the Williston Basin. Folks, if you haven’t seen it, you don’t know the half of it. TRADING STRATEGIES: JULY Brighter days?    • • • Let’s put a smile on your Facebook • Independent thinkers are buying banks • Shorter is better when it comes to bonds • Emerging markets may be July’s best play • The time has come for natural gas • How to play the Bakken boom • Master the possibilities of Mastercard • Range Resources powers up    China isn't the global growth engine it once was. Jeff Shen, head of the Asia-Pacific and emerging-market equity group at BlackRock tells MarketWatch's Jonathan Burton what he sees as the biggest threat to China's economy. What I saw was a legitimate boom, the type that leads to cities being built and economies being stimulated. Infrastructure upgrades including roads, telecommunications, electrical, bridges, rail lines and pipelines were apparent not only near the boom town of Williston, but throughout the region. Subdivisions are also being constructed for the tens of thousands of people moving into the area. Driving the growth is one of the best oil deposits in America. The Williston Basin is a closed system, essentially a 200,000-square-mile rock bowl filled with multiple layers of petroleum, including oil and natural gas liquids. The Bakken shale gets the most press, however, there are multiple recoverable levels, called benches, in different formations, including the Three Forks. The oil being pumped from the Williston Basin is both economical to recover and easy to refine. The Bakken oil is high-grade light sweet crude that is among the best oil on the continent, far cleaner than oil sands petroleum from Canada. The oil flows so freely in the basin that we saw many newer wells that didn’t need the help of a pump to fill storage tanks. In studying industry and state records, it appears that wells that do not produce are few and far between. This basin is largely responsible for the United States becoming an exporter of fuel in 2011 for the first time in six decades and likely an exporter again in 2012. So far, there are about 7,000 active wells in the basin, some older. The pace is picking up on drilling, as in order to hold leases, about 5,000 new wells will need to be completed in the next few years. It will take approximately 45,000 wells, which use about 4 miles of steel pipe each, to tap the basin of what is likely 10 to 20 billion barrels of oil. Drilling will go on for about a decade or slightly longer, and wells will produce for about three decades at decreasing rates. While this is not a game changer in and of itself, combined with other American oil plays and abundant natural gas reserves, it appears America’s bridge to renewable and sustainable energy is found. What is especially important about the Williston Basin is that it will be partly responsible for the United States becoming energy self-sufficient, as Continental Resources CEO Harold Hamm calls it. In the next few years, America will be able to reduce OPEC’s contributions to our petroleum supply to a few percent of total supply. Hamm’s analysis jives with a report put out by Goldman Sachs late in 2011. This energy self-sufficiency will obviously do wonders for America (see my letter “Freedom From OPEC“ at www.KirkSpano.com), as we will not be beholden to less friendly or difficult foreign nations for the oil that we use for the first time in decades. A better supply ought to keep prices down at the pump and our military commitments will likely reduce. Already, we have largely left Iraq to the Chinese to worry about, as China has won most of the oil field contracts there. Most importantly for American competitiveness, is that our energy costs, due to both oil and gas production at home, will be lower than nations we had been exporting jobs to the past few decades. That will give incentive for companies to move jobs back to America. As those jobs come back over the rest of the decade, what I have called the “halo effect” will take hold. Other industries will thrive (remember all that steel used per well), pushing unemployment down and creating a virtuous economic cycle. For the investor, some of the smaller oil companies appear very worthy of investment. I have profiled and discussed Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.58% Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43%  and Triangle Petroleum TPLM, -11.43%  on the Trading Deck, and each is a buy right now in my opinion given the recent drop in oil prices and negative market sentiment. For those three companies, I have been using a mixed strategy of selling puts, buying stock and buying calls. Continental Resources CLR, -3.60%  and Whiting WLL, -4.08%  are larger oil companies that also present interesting opportunities on share price pullbacks. Oil services companies, such as Halliburton HAL, -2.83%  and Flotek FTK, -4.26%  are also seeing growth worth consideration for investment. Companies in industries once removed from oil, such as in steel, railroad and trucking are also worthy of research. Regardless of where you decide your best stock (or business or employment) opportunities are, this is a real boom in America, and it can make you money. content: I never attempt to make money on the stock market. I buy on the assumption that they could close the market the next day and not reopen it for five years. —Warren Buffett In 2011, if you had an equity portfolio and left it alone all year, presuming you did not make any terrible mistakes, not trading was a great idea. While you would have hovered around zero return, you would not have gotten clobbered like so many traders and hedge funds did. 2012 is proving to be much the same as 2011; bouts of volatility, but not much overall movement, although I maintain that very well could change for the positive soon. What we know about trading is that there are very few winners. While the best traders make a lot of money by beating most of the others (a lot like poker), there are almost no retail investors among the winners. If you must trade, taking a slow-hand position-trading approach with companies and sectors that you have fundamentally qualified is probably the way to go. Position trading is seeking to catch major moves over an extended period of time from a particular company or sector. Unlike active traders who are looking to move in an out frequently, a position trader who uses fundamental analysis in selecting companies and sectors will trade infrequently, only trading out when the major move has ended or market conditions become extreme. Today, investors who are stuck in cash or bonds have a great chance to start fundamentally choosing stocks and sectors to buy and hold for a pretty long time. As Buffett has also said, "You do things when the opportunities come along. I've had periods in my life when I've had a bundle of ideas come along, and I've had long dry spells. If I get an idea next week, I'll do something. If not, I won't do a damn thing." Right now, I have a bundle of ideas. As those who have followed my articles the past eight months know, I have a pretty simple thesis: An economic collapse is not imminent, the world economy already collapsed (2007-09, in case you missed it). What is going on now is the slow, painful, disgustingly frustrating and labored re-birth of the global economy. The world is not done growing by simple virtue of the fact that there are billions of people who want better standards of living. Scarcity will increase over the next two to three decades until sustainability models and alternative energy take hold. Europe will gradually pull through (I'm tired of using the word "muddle" because so many people have adopted it) in an ugly, but fairly brilliant way, as they save the euro from attack by speculators and those motivated to blow it up for other reasons. The United States will eventually do things right after trying almost everything else. America is poised to boom as she is flush with many of the necessities of life, i.e. food and natural resources; strong in manufacturing high-end goods, i.e. machinery, medicine and technology; strong in skilled services, and very importantly, has a new large generation about to hit the workforce. While rampant pessimism and fear exists among investors lamenting the past 12 years, that simply makes it a good, and maybe great, time to invest in stocks. The neat thing about mass investor psychology is that it offers some wonderful opportunities to go against the grain. My best ideas, which I have written about repeatedly, and do again in the Trading Strategies section next week, continue to be small and mid-size oil companies and oil services companies with operations in the Williston Basin. I have already discussed Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.58% Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43%  and Triangle Petroleum TPLM, -11.43% All of these are buys as they have been severely beaten the past several months and are just starting to reverse. Also, in my "best" universe, is Exact Sciences EXAS, -2.06% which is still speculative due to being in a Phase III FDA clinical trial, but by virtue of being up hundreds of percent for me, qualifies as a best idea I suppose by definition of the word best. I have a host of other ideas, which I have written about here and elsewhere, including today posting the mid-year summary of my firm's core holdings. What are your best ideas? If you don't know, it's time start looking forward again, building a fundamentally strong list and stop looking backward — you can't change the past anyway. content: "Go west, young man." — Horace Greeley Today I drove about 700 miles from my suburban Milwaukee home to Jamestown, North Dakota. I'm about three hours from Minot, where on Thursday morning, I will meet up with Bob Walstad of Integrity Viking Funds and co-manager of the Williston Basin Mid-North America Stock Fund ICPAX, +2.46% before setting out for a guided tour of the oil patch. One of the things I've learned so far is that Jamestown, which is a sleepy little town when Jamestown College is out, is very difficult to get a hotel room in, despite being five hours from the City of Williston, the epicenter of the oil boom in North Dakota. As told by several hotel personal, men working in the oil industry, are sharing the rooms in shifts and from week to week depending on who is working when. Intriguing to me is that there is downtown real estate still available in Jamestown, only about a mile from the college. In talking to the very sweet Cathy at the front desk, of the very comfortable Gladstone Inn & Suite's where I am staying, it is apparent that Jamestown is going through some changes. Located along Interstate 94, within a few hours of a major oil boom, a few other nearby job catalysts and with a charming downtown, the Buffalo City appears to be a town on the come. While eating dinner at Grizzley's, I had the opportunity to talk to a few truckers. Each of them made the point that Williston was a little wild right now, but that the money was flowing. One gentleman hauled fracking mud from Michigan, which he described as being used to water proof the piping used in the drilling process. He was quite knowledgeable about the process and believed that, from an environmental standpoint, the drilling companies were being very diligent about protecting the ground water, if nothing else to protect their golden goose. The bartender described the flow of people moving through the area as being very regular and was good enough to warn me about one of the nearby restaurants. She was pretty sure her home had gone up in value in the past couple of years as well, which is saying a lot in America recently. She was also quite good at putting a head on my pint of Fat Tire beer. I have prepared a list of questions from Mr. Walstad about what we are going to see, which should be several drilling sites, including for Whitting Petroleum WLL, -4.20% Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43% Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.70% and Continental Resources CLR, -3.68% In talking to him a few times by telephone now, it won't take a lot of prodding from me to get a lot of great information. He is a virtual encyclopedia of knowledge about what is going on in the oil industry and the Williston Basin in particular. I am going to keep this column short as I've had a long day, but want to remind people that what is going on in North Dakota is a big deal. I have written several columns about it now and will write several more, including one for Monday. The companies involved in the Williston and the companies serving those companies, are some of the most compelling growth opportunities in America. The halo effect is significant. Consider, it takes about four miles of steel piping to complete one well, and that there are projected to be thousands of new wells over the next few years. On this trip, I am not only looking to gain even greater insight into companies I already own, but to find a few more to buy. Already, these companies are finding their way into several of my firm's investment strategies because these companies offer not only growth, but because of the options that are available, offer some very interesting positive asymmetric opportunities. content: Tonight, I was watching the last episode of House and had no intention of writing, but the show helped me clarify something that had been on my mind the past few months. I have been wondering, painfully trying to figure out really, what the baby boomers, who are so damaged by their experience in the stock market the past 12 years, are going to do now? I wonder about that for two reasons. Second, because the answer is central to whether stock markets lead the economic recovery that I believe is just beginning or trail it for the rest of this decade, before the time when Generation Y starts investing enough money to make an impact. First, however, I wonder how the baby boomers are ever going to afford an enjoyable retirement if they don't put more of their money back into stocks? Michael Gayed has been talking about how he expects a switch from fixed income into stocks. His logic is hard to dispute. I have been thinking the same thing, logically. However, there is something more to it than the logic that bonds are near all-time high prices and stocks are at worst fairly valued as a class. That thing, is emotion. People are deathly afraid that they will lose money in the stock market the next decade and harm their retirement. The problem with that line of reasoning for most boomers however is that they are already behind the eight ball in regard to retirement. Consider your study of choice, the baby boomers are woefully short on retirement savings and pensions. The boomers who do have six-figure portfolios are worried they might lose tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars if they invest in the stock market again. They are afraid of the wrong bogeyman however. Inflation is coming. In fact, inflation in necessities is already here. That type of inflation, though, is central to the boom that I forecast for America as an exporter of food, energy, high-end machinery, medicine and technology. Unfortunately, baby boomers won't participate in the upside of America as a growth export economy again if they are not invested in stocks, because they are working less by the day as a group and can't count on wages. They, in fact, will suffer as prices, even if there is a firmer dollar as I expect, of necessities drift upward due to the effects of global scarcity on supply and demand curves. I understand the baby boomer's trepidation to buying stocks. It is very understandable and reasonable. But since most boomers are conspiracy theorists in my experience, let me toss something out there that might stir some to invest again: The very rich are buying resource and certain manufacturing, medicine and technology stocks at a time when computer-driven volatility makes it extra scary to invest. Ask why that is. You might find a motivating conspiracy theory to spur some investment. You might not find that theory though. You might just decide it’s a bunch of greedy people—some smarter or less dumb than others—along with global debt issues and coincidence that have led to the volatile markets. Whatever you decide are the reasons behind the scary, here is what I know today: The baby boomers are in bad shape financially, have had a rough go of it in the stock market the past 12 years and are afraid of stocks. America is on the verge of becoming a major food, energy, high-end machinery, medicine and technology growth export economy again due to global demand from emerging and mature economies alike. Some of the most astute investors in the world are accumulating shares in businesses that will benefit from America becoming a supplier to offset global scarcity (this should be a tip off). That the baby boomers better get over their backward looking fear of stocks. For the weary boomer, here is an investment that can be used as the warm blanket to get back into the stock market: General Electric GE, -2.37%  pays a fat dividend, has corrected it is financial problems and is a major player in energy. It is once again the slow growth income play that you can count on. For younger investors, say anybody not yet retired, look to the Williston Basin for Bakken oil shale investments. I have discussed this theme several times, so look at my article list, but I believe Williston Basin related stocks are, as a group, possibly the best opportunity on earth right now. Look at Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43% Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.58% Flotek FTK, -3.93% and CJ Energy Services CJES, +0.00% for relatively safe opportunities to make excess returns. So, how did watching the last episode of House get me to write this? I don't know. Maybe it has something to do with renewal, making choices to live life to the fullest in our limited time here or opening oneself up to new paths of thought. Maybe my brain just slowed down watching TV. I'm sure several commentators will go with the slow brain theory. content: This column was originally headlined "Synthetic Oil," which I thought was pretty clever. But after getting home Thursday night, I decided there was more to talk about. This column might drag on, so I'll try to be interesting for all of my single-serving friends. For those who have read my other pieces, I think you'll understand. In my career, the one problem I have run into consistently with investors is that most people are not really investors. Most people seeking financial advice or a financial planner are savers who are trying to keep up with inflation. There's nothing wrong with that and I can help them with what they need. Today though, I am thinking bigger than narrowly beating inflation with as low of risk as possible (the low risk is what requires skill). I am thinking about generating the sort of wealth that improves people's level of freedom, and hopefully enables some of them to do more of the good things that are in their hearts. For myself, and investors who hire me, I want to take advantage of the sort of opportunity that only comes around periodically. I want to participate in the American resource boom that I see developing. The developing boom for America will be a long, multiple-stage series of events. Each opportunity will be a little different. The first in the series, the one knocking on the door, is based upon expanding domestic oil production and fuel exports. This has already started. Production in the United States is up dramatically the past several years. In addition, in 2011, the United States exported fuel for the first time in six decades. What you see in the EIA chart above is a significant ramp up of oil (liquids) production. This increase will level off in the next decade, but between now and early next decade, the surge in production will continue. As I have discussed, many oil companies are about to see a surge in profits as well due to a growing export market for American fuel. This is a large opportunity that most "investors" are missing. In discussing Bakken oil companies, one strategy I touched on included using options to create a synthetic long position by selling a put and buying a call. The benefit vs. simply being long a stock is that the investor gains leverage on the position which if a catalyst materializes during the term of the call option, can generate a multiple on the position. In this type of trade, if the underlying stock falls in price during the option term, the investor buys the stock via having it put to them, presuming the put is left open. In many cases, it becomes apparent about two weeks from expiration that closing the position and cutting losses is a good idea, in which case the investor saves some money. If the stock rises, but only a bit, then the options all expire and the investor simply reloads a similar trade having lost nothing but some calendar. Four companies I am using this sort of strategy for are Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43% Triangle Petroleum TPLM, -11.43% Northern Gas and Oil NOG, +1.26%  and Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.58% I am looking at adding Apache Corporation APA, -2.36%  now. Being able to generate a multiple on your investments is the second key to significantly outperforming the markets. The first, of course, is picking the right companies to invest in to begin with. For the investor seeking more downside protection, in case I am wrong and oil companies are about to run into hard times, utilizing protective puts will be useful. For larger accounts, paying for this sort of basic hedging will help preserve wealth in the case of hard pullback. There is little point in hedging a five-figure account however in my opinion. The costs are too high, so utilize trailing stops instead. A problem that many, if not most, people have with investment strategies is not following through. Missing on a trade, even if it was a good idea, leads too many folks to move onto something else. Often, the right approach is to try again, just like a batter who swings and misses. So long as investors mitigate losses, capital will stay intact enough to get into the batters box again and again and again until there is an extra base hit. The first batch of trades I discussed have not completed yet. Prices on the underlying stocks have fallen however, meaning that opening new positions now is more favorable than before. Investors ought to look into a synthetic long strategy as Bakken oil plays have a bright future. The Eagle Ford shale is also going to create some large winners as well. Don't neglect the oil services companies. Most of my accounts are already tilted toward participating in the developing oil boom. And while what I am doing is not completely original, most investors are still sitting in their broadly diversified portfolios essentially indexing on the not cheap and taking 100% of the market risk in doing so. I would hopefully like to wake at least some of those people up today. Here is a quote to think about: "Wide diversification is only required when investors do not understand what they are doing." Warren Buffett I have written two articles referencing this investing sin, here and here. The thing is, like I said, most people are not investors. That's really the crux of why so many people underperform long-term. Become an investor. Find a few good ideas and commit to them. Probably not with all of your money, but with some amount that is comfortable. With the rest, build a nice balanced, low-cost asset allocation that will beat inflation by a bit. At the beginning of the article, I mentioned the article was called "Synthetic Oil." Here's how I started. We all know how good synthetic oil is for certain cars. Now, using a synthetic investment strategy using options to go long on oil stocks might be just as good for your portfolio. Are you an investor? If so, focusing more on oil is a good idea and using options for a part of the strategy might make a good idea better. content: In the past month, Bakken-oil-related stocks have paused after a large autumn and early winter move up. The group continues to be under some light pressure as oil prices moderate due to fears of further global economic malaise. This is a buying opportunity. While the world economic recovery is no doubt tenuous, as I have mentioned in various other articles, I am not highly fearful of another major deflationary collapse as we saw in 2008. It is almost a certainty in my view that either the world economy keeps muddling along toward more sustained growth, or governments step in to stimulate growth. In both cases, many commodity producing companies remain attractive in general. Any short-term pullbacks are chances to buy in my view. In the Bakken oil shale play, many of the companies share prices have fallen from their early year price highs. Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43% which continues to ramp up production, has seen its shares drop to the middle $9s off of a $10.90 high. Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.83% also ramping up production on its highly desirable acreage, is near $31 per share, down from a high of $35.46. Northern Oil and Gas NOG, +1.77% with its non-operator strategy, has fallen to the middle $19s per share from a high of $28. Triangle Petroleum TPLM, -11.43% making the transition from non-operator to operator, has slid back to $6.20 from a high of $8.40. I have covered this particular group earlier, discussing the possibility that each could be acquired by larger oil companies. I have also discussed an option strategy that looks even better now at the lower share prices. Two catalysts are at work with the Bakken group. The first has been mentioned a bit in the news already, and that is the effect of good weather in North Dakota this winter. Rig count jumped in January and February according to numbers by Baker Hughes and slightly different numbers by the Industrial Commission of North Dakota - Oil & Gas Division, to reach a new high during the usually slower winter period. With added crews for many companies, rig count will continue to increase. By the end of the year, it is expected that Bakken oil production approaches total Alaskan production. With about 99% of drilled wells hitting oil and 90% profitable, the added rigs should add to company bottom lines by the end of the year, and quite possibly sooner. Also in the news are the Seaway and Keystone oil pipelines. The Seaway is about to have a significant impact on the Bakken stocks. Beginning in late May, about 150,000 barrels of oil per day will be able to move away from Cushing, Oklahoma and make its way to Gulf refining facilities. Within two years, that capacity is planned to be 450,000 barrels. The current glut of oil in the middle of the country has suppressed oil prices for producing Bakken companies, keeping it about $10 per barrel below prevailing Cushing spot prices (though there was an oft-quoted trough price in February) and even further below international spot prices. This has made profit margins tighter than desired at some companies and led at least indirectly to a few of the smaller companies barely missing estimates in the previous quarter as their drilling expenses were higher with the new rigs. With the reversal of the Seaway pipeline almost complete, Bakken companies can look forward to receiving a price for their oil that is essentially the same as the price at Cushing, though redirected Bakken oil could have the impact of slightly lowering Cushing prices. That money will hit both the top and bottom lines fairly quickly. Another company to look at is Continental Resources CLR, -3.61% the largest Bakken producer which is run by Mitt Romney's energy advisor Harold Hamm. With more of their oil freed to make it to gulf refiners, who will export some of the refined fuel, the company stands to see a surge in profits. Currently the shares trade with a price-to-earnings ratio exceeding 30, however, the forward p/e is only about 18, which does not appear to account for higher prices on the oil they will sell at Cushing soon. It is very possible that Continental sees big beats on earnings in a coming quarter. I am considering a put-selling strategy to bring in option premiums. For the fund investor, the Integrity Williston Basin/Mid-North America Stock Fund ICPAX, +2.46%  bought at net asset value is a good way to pick up a long-term position in the group. To buy the fund without a load, an investor would need their own online brokerage account or to work with a reasonably priced fee-only advisor (I know one), and not buy through a full service broker, who will take a 5% commission on the purchase. I would expect positive surprises for quite a few Bakken oil companies during the rest of the year. Buying now, would be appropriate for the right accounts. content: Six weeks ago, I highlighted four oil exploration and production companies operating primarily in the Bakken shale play that were all potential acquisition targets. Three of these companies are up a bit, but have become rangebound recently due to a spate of higher-than-anticipated operating expenses. Here are the charts of the four companies: Kodiak Oil and Gas KOG, -2.43%   TimeTriangle Petroleum Corp.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:TPLM $0.04 $0.06 $0.08  Northern Oil and Gas NOG, +2.02%    GAMES Week 2 results TrainingID edges out TheSugarBear by a mere 75 cents to win round two of MarketWatch's quarterly competition. Join the competition now! Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.70%   Triangle Petroleum TPLM, -11.43%   . . . . . . . . In looking at the charts, Kodiak looks like the most likely to break out. The company did experience higher-than-expected expenses in the most recent quarterly report, but a portion of that can be attributed to being ahead of schedule in drilling due to mild weather in December. The company is trading at about a forward P/E of 8, and if it ramps drilling a bit faster than lowered expectations, it could see its share price surge. Oasis is looking pretty good technically, too, potentially coming out of a pivot up, off a double bottom. It reported good earnings and outlooks a couple of weeks ago and is ramping revenue quickly. With very experienced management, it is hard to see this company not doing well. Triangle's chart is ambiguous at this point in my opinion, but I think the company might be the most ripe for a takeover based upon its size and other factors. If they get their new wells into operation before the stated summer anticipation dates, these shares could jump. Given the mild winter and clear focus on the North Dakota part of their portfolio over the less-proven Montana portion, I think it is likely the new wells produce sooner than expected or at least on time. The company is weirdly debt-free to boot. Northern is the weakest in the bunch technically, trending down. Catching this gently falling knife might produce big gains if done well. However, given the volatility of oil stocks, you could get cut as well. Given Northern's partnership strategy, I don't see their weakness lasting long. The question is how to take a position. I am using a basket approach to these companies by owning some stock and holding some bullish and neutral option positions. The option strategy I am using is fairly simple. I am selling puts and buying calls with the collected premiums. My downside is that I will potentially have to buy some stock in companies that I like at a little less net cost than today's price later in the year. My upside is that I capture amplified gains if there is a surge in these particular oil stocks. Kodiak puts with a $10 strike price (about today's share price) have a bid of $1.45. Selling those generates $1.45 per share in premium. An investor’s obligation is that you may have to buy the stock at $10 between now and the third Friday in September. Using the $1.05 of the put premium collected to buy June $10 calls, an investor would still have a net .40 per share in their account and get the upside of the June calls. For example, if Kodiak rises to $15 between now and June, the investor will be able to sell those calls for $5 (plus any time value that is left), far in excess of the 50% gain if the stock were simply bought. If the stock is under $10 come September, an investor could buy the stock for a net cost of $9.60, which is the $10 strike price minus the 40¢ premium held. There are similar strategies using the other Bakken stocks mentioned. I am also using a sell-puts/buy-calls strategy across two stocks. I have sold some puts on Northern Oil and Gas and used the premium to buy calls on Oasis. I make a few dimes on the deal and get the short-term upside of Oasis which might be developing momentum, in addition to its fundamental positives. If there is a setback in these stocks, I might end up having to buy Northern Oil and Gas for a little cheaper net cost than today's price, which is fine since I like it in for the long run. In using the sell puts and buy calls strategy, there is also the possibility that all of the options expire unexcercised, in which case the gain is small. While not sexy, it is better than a sharp stick in the eye. If the options all expire, rinse and repeat is what I generally do. I know this seems fairly complex to non-option traders, but learning basic option strategies can be a great way to get more upside with the same downside as buying stocks outright. With the companies discussed, getting that extra short run upside could result in big gains for any number of reasons, such as war in Iran, an oil disruption somewhere else in the world, stronger than expected economic growth numbers, acquisition or revenue and/or earnings beats by the companies which get ahead on their drilling due to good weather. content: As discussed last week, improvements in hydraulic fracturing has led to vast opportunities for oil and gas service companies that can stay on the right side of the EPA. As most readers know, fracking is also providing significant growth for many oil and gas exploration and production companies in America. This rapid growth is now also creating the circumstances for increased mergers and acquisition activity. Among the fastest growing oil and gas companies and those with the biggest potential are those involved with the Bakken and Three Forks formations in the Williston Basin of North Dakota and to a lesser extent Montana. North Dakota's rich reserves and friendly attitude towards drillers makes it a prime place for oil and gas production. As of last month North Dakota drillers reached 500,000 barrels of oil (and equivalents) per day of production. That curve, presuming no outright shut down of fracking by the Federal Government, appears likely to hit 1,000,000 barrels per day within a few years. Given the intermediate and longer term supply and demand picture for oil and gas, there is a clear desire for companies to control as much strategic reserves as possible. North Dakota has somewhere between 11 billion barrels of oil, according to the North Dakota Geological Survey, and 24 billion barrels of oil, according to Harold Hamm founder of the largest Bakken acreage holder, Continental Resources CLR, -3.43% that is recoverable. This is reserves for several decades even at double today's production and could provide as much as 20% of America's oil needs. Already, acquisitions are beginning to occur. In October of 2011, Statoil purchased Brigham Exploration with its Bakken assets for $4.4 Billion. This purchase by the Norwegian major translated into about $12,000 per acre for access to the high growth area. Further deals seem only a matter of time and will likely be at higher prices per acre. Acreage control in North Dakota is highly fragmented due to the recent and nearly simultaneous realization of the potential of the Williston Basin. Several smaller companies however are highly leveraged to the area and control acreage that is likely highly attractive to the oil and gas majors. I have four companies I am seeking entry prices for which are growing, control attractive land and are potentially likely to seek being acquired at some point soon. The smallest North Dakota acreage holder in the group is Triangle Petroleum TPLM, -11.43% Triangle has a duel strategy of developing about 81,000 acres in the Bakken region, as well as, an 87% ownership in about 474,000 acres in Nova Scotia. The company is looking at strategic opportunities with its Nova Scotia property. It would not be a big surprise to see Triangle seek a buyer for its Bakken acreage if it believed it could use the proceeds to exploit its Canadian opportunities which are relatively low-cost. Triangle's Bakken acreage, using a small premium to the Statoil-Brigham deal could fetch the company over $1 billion. The company's market cap now is only $300 million and it carries little to no debt. Next on the acreage list is Kodiak KOG, -2.43% itself an acquirer including some already producing tracts. Kodiak is holding about 155,000 acres in the Bakken. Much of its land is adjacent to majors which might wish to acquire it. Kodiak also has a secondary play in the Green River Basin in southern Wyoming and northern Colorado. The company appears to have overcome some perceived financing risks and is ramping up production. Given the good weather so far this winter, if it is not acquired soon, it could see further share price appreciation as it increases production. Its acreage is valued at roughly $2 billion. The company has a market cap of about $2 billion and debt of under $100 million. Similar to Kodiak in acreage is Northern Oil and Gas NOG, +2.02% with about 160,000 net acres in the Bakken and Three Forks. Northern is focused on a low expense strategy as a non-operator by having partners handle the drilling of its property. Its return on assets is ahead of many other small cap companies nearing 10%. It anticipates adding 44 wells in 2012 to the 40 it added in 2011. Northern's acreage is also valued about $2 billion. With a market cap of only $1.5 billion and little debt the company could be a compelling value to an acquirer. Northern already has relationships with several larger companies. If Northern is not acquired, I can see them beginning to pay a dividend in the near future. Rounding out the four potential targets is the largest acreage holder, Oasis Petroleum OAS, -3.33% with 303 acres. Oasis is a pure play on the Williston Basin. Its property is essentially right next door to the Brigham property that Statoil bought just a few months ago. Oasis has sold off some of its more difficult to develop land, leaving it about 250,000 acres that are likely to be developed over time. Oasis is returning over 10% on assets and has no immediate liquidity issues owing to its low cost of original land acquisition at around $450 per acre. The company can choose to grow over time or be selective if suitors turn up. Due to the large acreage it controls, the 10th largest in the region according to industry statistics, it could command a larger premium than some of the smaller plays mentioned in this article, possibly fetching as much as $5 billion. The company has a market cap of a mere $3 billion. This is another company that could begin paying a dividend soon. content: --Fund focuses on small-cap companies --Fund has tried to limit its exposure to European debt crisis --Manager says he prefers lesser-known industries and equities NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- For T. Rowe Price small-capitalization fund manager Preston G. Athey, companies with flash and familiarity aren't necessarily selling points. "When they are household names and they have sexy stories, they tend not to be values," said Athey, who manages the $6.9 billion T. Rowe Price Small-Cap Value fund PRSVX, +0.98% "I am trolling around in the backwaters, looking for industries and companies that the world doesn't know about." The fund--with more than 300 equities in industries that range from oil and natural gas to logistics to appliance rentals--targets companies with a market capitalization of between $100 million and about $3 billion, promising investors a slow and steady return. Athey said he has worked to protect his fund from exposure to the debt crisis in Europe by selecting stocks that are focused primarily on North America. "If you own some American companies that have very little in the way of exports, this is at least one way you can invest," said Athey. "I've got dozens of these things." The fund's focus on lesser-known companies has helped it return more than 17% over the past three years on an annualized basis, though the fund declined less than 1% in 2011, according to Morningstar Inc. That compares with a return of 12% over the past three years and 0.9% in 2011 at Morningstar's U.S. Value index. Morningstar rates the fund four stars out of five and said its overall return is "above average." Athey said he likes Signature Bank SBNY, -2.06% and SVB Financial Group SIVB, -2.57% which runs Silicon Valley Bank, because they are sheltered from loans to Greece and other embattled European countries. Signature returned 20% last year through Dec. 30, while SVB dropped 10%. SVB makes loans to venture capitalists, who Athey said generally invest in U.S. companies. "This is the bank that almost every venture-capital firm banks with, so I am not particularly worried about their prospects if something bad happens in Europe." Barge operator Kirby Corp. KEX, -0.06% comprising less than 1% of the fund's holdings, was one of its top performers in 2011, gaining 49% through Dec. 30. Athey said that due to cheaper gasoline prices Dow Chemical Co. DOW, -0.77% and E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co. DD, +0.94% among others, are exporting more petrochemicals, benefitting Kirby, which moves chemicals within the U.S. "The longer that gas prices stay low, the more our exports will be advantaged," said Athey. "Kirby is in a great position to take advantage of that." Small oil and gas companies will also play an important role in the fund's future, said Athey. He recommends Oasis Petroleum Inc. OAS, -3.58% and Northern Oil & Gas Inc. NOG, +2.02% for growth in the coming year. The fund is also poised to grow from investments in health-care companies that aren't exposed to Europe. "You can't get away from nursing homes, we continue to have an aging population," said Athey. That's why he will continue investing in National HealthCare Corp. NHC, +0.49% which provides long-term health care services, he said. National HealthCare was down 9.4% last year through Dec. 30. "All these companies are oblivious to what's happening in Europe," said Athey. "They're doing their thing here in the U.S." Athey said he likes to invest in companies and hold onto them for years. In the past 10 years, the fund has averaged about 10% turnover among its holdings, compared with as much as 50% for other small-cap funds, said Athey. "If it's a sexy, high-growth company, it'll probably be way too expensive," he said. content: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services raised its outlook on Oasis Petroleum Inc. OAS, -3.64% citing the exploration and production company's speedy progress growing its asset base. Oasis was formed in 2007 to acquire and develop oil and gas fields in a portion of the largely undeveloped Williston Basin in Montana and North Dakota. The company has reported higher production and strong top line growth since it went public last year. The ratings firm pointed specifically to the company's growing asset base, which helped boost production volumes 110% over the prior-year quarter. S&P now rates Oasis at B, five steps below investment grade. The current status reflects the company's small asset base and low production levels relative to its peers, along with its heavy geographic concentration, an aggressive growth strategy, a limited operating track record, previously weak accounting control processes and negative cash flow generation. At the same time, Oasis benefits from high crude oil prices, a favorable cost structure, high growth potential and sizeable acreage position. The positive outlook could translate to a ratings upgrade if the company meets its production and reserve growth goals over the next several quarters, S&P said. Moody's Investor's Service rates the company at B3, a notch below S&P's rating, based on the company's small scale and limited operating history. Shares were recently off 15 cents at $32.23 Thursday. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Energy stocks strengthened Friday to finish out a positive week, as shares of BP, Transocean and Anadarko Petroleum regained some of their lost territory in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico. The NYSE Arca Oil Index XOI, -2.54% rose 0.8% to 978. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index XNG, -3.52% rose 0.3% to 544. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, -3.46% jumped 1.8% to 184. Among movers, Anadarko Petroleum APC, -4.60% which owns 25% of the stricken Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico, rose 2.3% to $42.57. Transocean RIG, -3.19% which owned the Deepwater Horizon rig that blew up on April 20, rallied 10% to $54.61. In the broad market, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -2.09% rose 16 points. In the commodities trading pits, crude oil futures advanced 35 cents to $77.14. Moody's downgraded BP PLC BP, -1.73% debt Friday by three notches to A2 from Aa2, affecting about $25 billion of the company's debt securities. U.S.-listed shares of BP rose a nickel to close at $31.76. The rating agency cited the "worsening impact" expected from the Gulf oil disaster caused by BP's blown-out well. Senior unsecured and BP-backed subsidiary long-term debt was slashed to A2 ratings. Moody's also cut its issuer rating on BP to A3 from Aa3. Separately BP PLC Chairman Carl-Henric Svanberg told Sky News Friday the oil major remains on track to carry out a June 4 plan to set up a new stand-alone unit to handle the Gulf of Mexico oil spill response operation under Bob Dudley, who currently serves as managing director for the company. BP CEO Tony Hayward announced the plan two weeks ago. Svanberg told Sky News that Hayward "is now handing over the operation to Bob Dudley" after leading the critical operation for eight weeks. BP spokesman Robert Wine declined to comment on Svanberg's remarks beyond the June 4 statement from the company. Among stocks in the spotlight, Oasis Petroleum Inc. OAS, -3.58% rose 7% to $15.96. On Thursday, shares closed at $14.88 in their first day of trading for a gain of 6%, or 88 cents, over its offering price of $14 a share. The company's initial public offering of 42 million shares raised $588 million as one of the richest U.S. deals this year. Houston-based Oasis Petroleum holds 292,000 net leasehold acres in the Williston Basin, an area bridging the Canadian border that includes much of the rich Bakken resources in North Dakota. In its IPO prospectus, Oasis cited a 2008 report by the U.S Geologic Survey that classified the formations as the largest continuous oil accumulation ever assessed in the contiguous United States. EnCap Investments LP manages funds listed as principal shareholders of Oasis Petroleum. Devon Energy Corp. DVN, -4.61% said it completed the sale of its Panyu field to China National Offshore Oil Corp. for $515 million, or approximately $370 million after tax. During 2009, Devon's production from the Panyu field was approximately 12,000 barrels of oil per day. Shares of Devon rose 0.6% to $69.92. El Paso Pipeline Partners LP EPB shares fell 4.8% to $28.50. The partnership priced 10 million common units at $28.80 per unit. Proceeds will be used as partial consideration for pending acquisition of an additional 16% general partner interest in Southern Natural Gas Co. from El Paso Corp, EP, +0.00% Energy stocks rise for the week Closing at 978 on Friday, the NYSE Arca Oil Index turned in a strong week, rising well above its ending point of 945 seven days ago. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index closed at 544 on Friday, above its close of 529 a week earlier. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index ended at 184 on Friday, 10 points above its ending point of 174 a week ago. content: The rise in crude oil prices over the past year has breathed some new life into U.S. energy producers. With crude prices remaining near or above $60 a barrel, the sector is recovering from a more than a year of low prices and falling stock prices. Analysts at Merrill Lynch have reviewed their energy portfolio and made some changes in price objectives and two ratings changes. The analysts also highlighted their top five picks following fiscal year 2017 earnings. Oasis Petroleum Inc. (NYSE: OAS) was downgraded from Neutral to Underperform on higher operational risk in the Delaware basin of the Permian. The company continues to be one of the standout operators in the Bakken, and while Merrill Lynch thinks the firm is "strategically sound, its expensive recent Permian acquisition may expose [Oasis] to incremental op risks in a red-hot basin with a sub-optimal scale (22k net acres)." The stock's price objective was cut from $11 to $9. The analysts upgraded Whiting Petroleum Corp. (NYSE: WLL) from Underperform to Neutral on what they see as early signs of a turnaround. Whiting has a new CEO who is laying out a clear strategic plan for balanced growth and cash flow neutrality. Merrill Lynch also noted: "Following solid 4Q17 results, we also like the incremental emphasis to monetize Redtail assets." The stock's price objective was lifted from $32 to $34. The analysts' five favorites are listed here with comments and price objectives. WPX Energy Inc. (NYSE: WPX): price objective raised from $19 to $20. Parsley Energy Inc. (NYSE: PE): price objective raised from $37 to $38. RSP Permian Inc. (NYSE: RSPP): price objective raised from $50 to $55. PDC Energy Inc. (NASDAQ: PDCE): price objective raised from $62 to $68. content: HOUSTON, Dec. 11, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Oasis Petroleum Inc. OAS, -4.69% ("Oasis" or the "Company") today announced it has entered into a definitive purchase and sale agreement with Forge Energy, LLC (the "Seller") to acquire 20,300 net acres in the Delaware Basin (the "Permian Assets") for approximately $946 million, consisting of approximately $483 million in cash and 46 million shares of the Company's common stock (the "OAS Shares") valued at approximately $463 million as of the close of trading on December 8, 2017 (the "Acquisition").  The Acquisition will be funded through a combination of the OAS Shares issued to the Seller, a draw on the Company's revolving credit facility, and/or capital markets transactions, depending on market conditions. Additionally, Oasis expects to divest non-core Williston Basin acreage up to $500 million in 2018. The Acquisition has an effective date of December 1, 2017 and is expected to close in February 2018, at which time the owners of the Seller will receive full consideration less a deposit paid. The transaction is subject to customary closing adjustments and conditions. Tommy Nusz, Oasis's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, commented "This accretive transaction more than doubles Oasis's core net inventory and represents a unique opportunity to acquire a highly complementary asset to Oasis's premier Williston Basin acreage that positions the Company to further capitalize on its operational strengths. Our leading track record of efficient full field development in the Williston Basin positions Oasis to succeed as we expand operations into the Delaware Basin. Our new Permian Assets deliver a consolidated position in the deepest and highest pressured part of the Delaware in the heart of the oil window. The Seller and offset operators have materially de-risked this position with recent well performance across the Wolfcamp and Bone Spring formations, giving us additional confidence in asset quality and well performance. This transaction further improves the capital efficiency of our development program, while providing an opportunity to divest and realize value for quality assets that fall deeper in our development program. We are excited for this new chapter, and also remain committed to our current capital-disciplined and returns-focused execution plan in the Williston Basin.  As we execute our combined program in 2018, we expect to be free cash flow positive on our E&P business running a $55 WTI oil price."  Acquisition Highlights Approximately 20,300 net acres acquired in the Delaware Basin across Loving, Ward, Winkler and Reeves Counties, Texas; Approximately 3,500 barrels of oil equivalent ("Boe") per day produced in November 2017 ($170 million PDP value at November 30, 2017 strip pricing); 601 gross operated locations (76% working interest) and 507 net core locations targeting the Wolfcamp A, B, and C and the Bone Spring formations, with extensive additional upside from other intervals in the column; Largely contiguous acreage blocks that allow for longer lateral development (expected median lateral length of approximately 8,000 feet); Ability to transfer technical, operational and managerial knowledge from full-field development of the Williston Basin to the Delaware Basin, in addition to future efficiencies from the vertical integration of Oasis Midstream Services LLC and Oasis Well Services LLC; Accretive to per-share NAV, long term cash flow, balance sheet, core inventory and overall inventory; Trading attractive non-core acreage in the Williston Basin for core Delaware Basin acreage; Expect to drill 16 to 20 gross wells and complete 6 to 8 gross wells with a capital program of approximately $100 million in 2018; and Initially running one rig with the potential to add a second rig in the second half of 2018 Recent Results and Updated Guidance Oasis production for October was approximately 70,000 Boe per day, and November operational production exceeded 72,000 Boe per day, already surpassing the planned 2017 exit rate. In light of the increased production, guidance for the fourth quarter of 2017 is increased from 69,000 – 72,000 Boe per day, to 71,000 – 73,000 Boe per dayOasis expects to continue to run five rigs in the Williston Basin, and will assume one rig currently run by the Seller in the Delaware Basin.  Additionally, Oasis expects lease operating expenses in the fourth quarter of 2017 to range between $7.00 and $7.50 per Boe and differentials to range between $0.50 and $1.00 per Boe. Oasis continues to expect production in the Williston Basin to exceed 83,000 Boe per day exiting 2018, not accounting for volumes to be divested through planned asset sales, and expects production to grow to over 5,000 Boe per day in the Delaware Basin exiting 2018. content: HOUSTON, Nov. 7, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Oasis Petroleum Inc. OAS, -4.63% ("Oasis" or the "Company") today announced financial results for the quarter ended September 30, 2017 and provided an operational update. Recent Highlights: Completed and placed on production 24 gross (15.1 net) operated wells in the Williston Basin in the third quarter of 2017. Produced 66.1 thousand barrels of oil equivalent per day ("MBoepd") in the third quarter of 2017, representing an increase of 7% over the second quarter of 2017, primarily driven by completion activity. Production during the third quarter of 2017 increased 36% over the third quarter of 2016. Produced over 69 MBoepd in October 2017 and expect to produce between 69 MBoepd and 72 MBoepd in the fourth quarter of 2017. Oasis continues to expect to hit an exit rate of 72 MBoepd, delivering 16% growth above the 2016 exit rate. Oil differentials have improved to $1.82 off of NYMEX West Texas Intermediate crude oil index price ("WTI") in the third quarter of 2017, and Oasis expects differentials in the fourth quarter to range from $1.25 to $2.00 off of WTI. Delivered Adjusted EBITDA of $179.6 million for the third quarter of 2017. For definitions of Adjusted EBITDA and reconciliations of Adjusted EBITDA to net income and net cash provided by operating activities, see "Non-GAAP Financial Measures" below. Commenced operations of its second Oasis Well Services ("OWS") frac crew during the third quarter of 2017. Oasis Midstream Partners LP ("OMP") sold 8,625,000 common units, representing limited partner interests in an initial public offering ("IPO" or the "Offering") for net proceeds of $137.2 million, of which $131.6 million was distributed to Oasis. Announced investment in and assignment of second Wild Basin Gas Plant ("Gas Plant II") with a total capacity of 200 million standard cubic feet per day ("MMscfpd") to service gas production from its highly economic inventory. Expects full year 2017 adjusted CapEx to total $620.0 million, in line with prior guidance. See "Capital Expenditures" below for adjustments. Including net proceeds distributed to Oasis from the OMP IPO and adjustments for the Gas Plant II assignment, Oasis generated positive free cash flow of $39.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2017. "Oasis successfully delivered on production growth during the quarter in line with guidance, completed its IPO of OMP, and launched its second frac crew," said Thomas B. Nusz, Oasis' Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. "The team delivered another great quarter and has positioned Oasis to exit the year with 72 MBoepd of production. Well performance across our core acreage position, including Wild Basin, Indian Hills, and Alger, continues to deliver impressive results, and our wells remain highly economic in the current commodity price environment. The team has also further reduced operating costs while driving improved differentials benefiting from our integrated midstream infrastructure." Gas Plant II Update Oil and gas production from Oasis' Wild Basin wells continues to exceed expectations, primarily due to higher frac intensity in the core areas of the Williston Basin.  The initial gas to oil ratio ("GOR") is generally higher in the core of the Williston Basin, including parts of McKenzie County, compared to the entire basin.  The combined effect of these factors has resulted in record gas production levels in the Williston Basin and particularly in McKenzie County where much of the drilling since 2015 has occurred, which now produces approximately half of the gas production in North Dakota. Due to the increased production of gas in the Williston Basin, there is a need for incremental processing capacity in the basin.   Gas production in Wild Basin has already surpassed original design expectations for OMP's 80 MMscfpd gas plant, which is held by OMP's wholly-owned development company ("DevCo"), Bighorn DevCo LLC ("Bighorn DevCo"), and recently has averaged gross gas production in Wild Basin of approximately 100 MMscfpd. Oasis initially evaluated options to process the incremental gas that is being produced in and around Wild Basin and subsequently began the front end engineering and design process for a second gas plant and began ordering long lead time items. Oasis recently made the decision to proceed with the construction of Gas Plant II, and on November 6, 2017, Oasis agreed to assign the project to OMP. In exchange for the assignment of Gas Plant II into Bighorn DevCo, OMP agreed to reimburse Oasis for 100% of the capital spent-to-date and will fund 100% of the remaining project capital. OMP funded the reimbursement under its revolving credit facility and will have full rights to all cash flows generated from both gas plants held by Bighorn DevCo. For the nine months ended September 30, 2017, Oasis invested $57.0 million in Gas Plant II, and on November 6,2017, assigned $66.7 million of asset value to OMP, which included capital spent in October 2017. OMP expects to invest approximately $140.0 million for the entire Gas Plant II project and anticipates operations will begin in late 2018. content: HOUSTON, Oct. 26, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Oasis Petroleum Inc. OAS, -4.38% ("Oasis" or the "Company") plans to announce its Third Quarter 2017 financial and operational results on Tuesday, November 7, 2017 after the close of trading on the NYSE. Additionally, the Company will host a live webcast and conference call on Wednesday, November 8, 2017 at 10:00 a.m. Central Time to discuss Third Quarter 2017 financial and operational results.
